Student council rules out
compulsory assemblies
The final decision concerning the
manner in which to conduct freshman assemblies was reached at the
Student council meeting last Friday.
The Council's decision was largely
influenced by a report presented by
Charles Fleagle, senior representative
to the Council. Fleagle was the head
of an assembly commision whose
duty was to conduct a poll of freshman opinion concerning assemblies
in general.
Sixty percent of the seventy letters
sent to freshmen were answered. All
those who replied to the poll unanimously agreed that they desired noncompulsory assemblies to take the
place of the former compulsory ones.
The chief comment that was given
was, "Make the assemblies more interesting and you will not have to
force us to come."
An Assembly committee controlled
by the Student council has been
formed consisting of the following
men: Charles Fleagle, chairman of
the newly-appointed committee; Sidney Thanhauser, freshman representative to the Council; Isadore Bernstein, chairman of the Pep Committee; and John Higham, managingeditor of the NEWS-LETTER. If it sees
fit, the committee will appoint a fifth
member. It is to have complete control over the conducting of assemblies; it is responsible only to the
Student council itself.

The non-compulsory assemblies are
to be held every other week. The
committee will plan them so that
they will be both entertaining and
advantageous to all those who attend.
Whenever freshmen must be informed of some campus activity or
of some other necessary information,
a compulsory meeting will be called
in addition to the other assemblies.
These meeting will be similar to the
Activities assembly held earlier this
year.
The compulsory meetings will be
exceptions to the general non-compulsory assembly rule and they will
be held infrequently.

The titles on the shelf of books
donated in honor of Broadus Mitchell
are certainly true mirrors of his
interests. Main Currents in American
Thought (economic interpretation),
Crisis in Socialism, and My Life as a
Rebel are all very suggestive of Dr
Mitchell. Now that the whole affair
of last spring is behind us I can't help
feeling that what we lost with his
resignation was not so much an effective leader of campus radicalism—
he was too well-known to be effective, paradoxical as it may seem.
People listened to him with preconceived notions about him. Our reactionaries took his course to be
amused. We lost, I think, a living
symbol of the right not to conform,
the most sacred right in a free man's
heritage. His unhappiness in non-conforming shows us all that to be different we must suffer and sacrifice.
What we saw last spring was not
a plot hatched by reactionaries. It
was rather a Greek tragedy—inevitable, yet no one was to blame.
* * *
The older I get the more I feel that
all of our "fundamental" problems
and ideas, all of our-soul-searching
and philosophising are mere shams
to cover up our inability to find resources within ourselves and other
men to keep us interested. I for one
find more in my afternoon ride home
on the Charles street bus to keep me
thinking than all the verbose nonsense in the newspapers. This does
not mean that my heart does not
bleed for suffering humanity. I love
democracy as much as the next one,
I suppose, but rather than hear a
lecture about it, I prefer to take a
walk.
